title: Use the Integration Studio
content:
This section provides guidelines on how to configure the Integration Studio.

  • It's a best practice to create, configure, and test integrations in the development tenant before you deploy them in the production tenant. The Integration Studio provides an import/export functionality that makes it easier for you to follow this best practice. For details, see Export and import integrations.
  • To use the Integration Studio, including creating or configuring Integration Studio-related endpoints, integrations, and scenarios, you must have the Integration Administrator role.

Step 1. Install and configure the OPB agent (optional)

If the source Service Management system can directly connect to the target system, there's no need to use the On-Premises Bridge (OPB) agent and you can skip this step.

If there's a web application firewall deployed in front of the target system, the source Service Management system needs to use the OPB agent to connect to the target system. For instance, if the source Service Management system is running on a public cloud and the target system is running in a firewalled on-premises environment, the source Service Management system needs to connect to the target system through the OPB agent. 

To use the OPB agent for an integration, perform the following steps:

  1. From the source Service Management system, download and install the OPB Agent. 
  2. Import the CA certificate of the source Service Management system into the OPB Agent's trusted keystore.
  3. Import the CA certificate of the target system into the OPB Agent's trusted keystore.
  4. In the source Service Management system, add an agent. 
  5. In the Endpoint Credentials Manager, create a credentials record for the target system with the Rest Executor Domain 2.0 endpoint type. The credentials record specifies the Auth Type, user name and password used to access the target system. This credential item will be used in the next step to configure endpoints. See Supported authentication types for Rest Executor 2.0 endpoints  for supported authentication types.

For details, see How to use On-Premises Bridge agents on Windows or How to use On-Premises Bridge agents on Linux. 

Step 2. Create an endpoint

To create an endpoint:

  1. Navigate to Administration > Utilities > Integration. 
  2. Go to Endpoints, and click Add to create an endpoint of the REST Executor 2.0 type. This endpoint type supports both agentless REST calls and REST calls through the OPB Agent. 
  3. Configure the endpoint.
    1. In the Agent field, select Agentless (if not using the OPB Agent) or the OPB agent created for the endpoint.
    2. If not using the OPB Agent, you need to specify the credentials of a user in the endpoint system and upload the endpoint certificate; if using the OPB Agent, you only need to select the credentials record created in the Endpoint Credentials Manager for the endpoint.
    3. See supported authentication types for more information about the authentication types. The supported connectors topic indicates the authentication type to use for each system.

    If Service Management must connect to the target system specified by the endpoint through a proxy server, configure the proxy server in the Suite Administration portal (Configurations > Proxy settings).

    Proxy server configuration isn't necessary if Service Management is deployed in a SaaS environment.

    Step 3. Create an integration

    To create an integration:

    1. Navigate to Administration > Utilities > Integration.
    2. Go to Integration Studio, and then click New.
    3. Enter a name for the integration and then click Save.

    4. Add connector-endpoint mappings for the systems that you want to integrate with in this integration. If the integration's scenarios contain only Local System rules, you can skip this step.

      Enter an alias for each connector-endpoint mapping. The alias should reflect the connector name and the environment characteristics of the target system. The Integration Studio will use the alias as the category name for actions of the target system when you add a rule.

      At maximum, you can add three connector-endpoint mappings in an integration.

      The Integration Studio doesn't support multiple connector-endpoint mappings in integrations that use an agent-based endpoint.
    5. Click   next to the Current system integration user field to enter the UPN and password for the integration user that you configured for this integration.
    6. Select the Active checkbox to activate the integration.
    7. Click Save.

    The Last modified by and Last modified time fields show who made the most recent changes and when they were made

    While using integration, if you want to be set free from Record Level Access Control during the execution, you need to override the entity's Record Level Access Control permissions in the role. This is applicable if the entity is set to Record Level Access Control in the studio.

    To duplicate an integration, hover over the integration, and then click the Duplicate ( ) icon. The duplicated integration (and its scenarios) will be in the inactive status, and you need to manually activate them after making the required changes.

    The system provides some Out-Of-The-Box (OOTB) integrations, which can be identified by the  icon. For such integrations, you can only update the Active field, the Current system integration user field and the Endpoint value in the Connector-Endpoint mappings section (if mappings are available). The operations that you can perform on scenarios included in the OOTB integrations are also limited: you can only update the Active field and the settings in the Listener section (if available).

    Step 4. Add and configure scenarios

    A scenario defines the integration process logic, and consists of a sequence of rules. You can add one or more scenarios to an integration.

    To add a scenario to an integration, perform the following steps:

    1. Open the integration page from Administration > Utilities > Integration > Integration Studio.
    2. In the left pane, select the integration where you want to add a scenario.
    3. Click Add scenario.
    4. Enter a name for the scenario.
    5. (Optional) To create the scenario based on a template, select the template. Only certain connectors have scenario templates defined. In the search box for the Template field, you can enter the template name or the connector name to search for a template with a specified name or templates available for a connector. To be able to use a template that is based on a particular connector, you must have added a Connector-Endpoint mapping for the connector in the integration.
    6. In the Mode field, select Asynchronous (default) or Synchronous.  Choose the mode based on the requirements of the target system and the scenario flow.
      • Asynchronous Mode: This is the default mode. On the Scenarios page, the  icon indicates asynchronous mode.
      • Synchronous Mode:  On the Scenarios page, the  icon indicates synchronous mode. You can use the Send Response action to define the response data. For details, see Send Response in Built-in actions. 
    1. (Optional) To trigger an integration scenario through the listener, select the Enable Listener check box. For details, see Listener.
    2. Click Save. The system adds the scenario.
    3. (Optional) To make the system fail any scenario rule with expression evaluation errors, select the Fail rule on expression evaluation error checkbox.
      Note that you can also configure this setting on the scenario rule level. If you want to enable this setting for individual rules, leave this checkbox unselected, and configure the setting on the rules instead. If you select the checkbox on the scenario level, the rule-level setting will be ignored.

    The Last modified by and Last modified time fields show who made the most recent changes and when they were made.

    To duplicate a scenario, hover over the scenario, and then click the Duplicate ( ) icon. The status of the duplicated scenario is inactive, activate it manually after making the required changes.

    To configure scenario rules, see Work with scenario rules.

    Step 5. Trigger an integration

    You can trigger an integration by using different methods depending on whether the scenario is in the asynchronous or synchronous mode.

    For asynchronous scenarios, use one of the following methods:

    • Business rule
    • Task plan
    • Listener
    • Scheduler 
    • Manually

    For synchronous scenarios, use one of the following methods:

    • Listener
    • Manually
    This section describes how to trigger the Integration Studio based on your needs. Some Service Management functionalities (such as Aviator) automatically trigger the Integration Studio according to their own logic. Those trigger types are not described here because they don't require configuration.

    Trigger integration by business rule

    To trigger an integration scenario through a business rule, perform the following steps:

    1. From the main menu, select Administration > Configuration > Studio.
    2. Select the record type from the drop-down box at the top of the screen and select the Processes and Rules tab.
    3. Select a node at the appropriate level of the tree in the left pane, and then click Add next to the After applying changes process event.
      You can add a Call Integration Studio rule only on the  After applying changes process event.
    4. Select Simple rule to define a rule without a condition, or select "If...Then" Rule to define a rule with a condition. The Set rule dialog box opens.
    5. In the Set rule dialog box, select Call Integration Studio under Integration Action, and then click OK.
    6. Under the After applying changes process event, click these parameters one by one:
      • Expression (optional): Configure a condition that must be satisfied for the integration scenario to be triggered.
      • Integration: Select the integration to be triggered.
      • Scenario: Select the specific scenario to be triggered.
      • Payload (optional): Click it to add key-value pairs to the payload that is passed to the scenario.
      To prevent the integration scenario from being triggered endlessly, you must configure this condition (on top of other required conditions) on the business rule: ${current_user.Upn!='<integration user>'}, where <integration user> is the UPN of the integration user configured in the integration being triggered.
    7. Click Save to save the rule.

    For details about business rules and how to add a business rule, see Related topics below.

    Trigger integration by task plan

    To trigger an integration scenario through a task plan, perform the following steps:

    1. From the main menu, go to the module that contains the record type for which a task plan can be built. For example, to build a task plan for the Change model record type, select Build > Change > Models. For a comprehensive list of record types that support task plans, see Task plans.
    2. Open a record for which to build the task plan.
    3. Go to the task/approval plan builder.
    4. Select a phase.
    5. Hover over the Start node, and click Edit.
    6. Select Automated task, and then enter the required information for the task.
    7. Click Set rule under Business rule.
    8. In the Set rule dialog box, select Call Integration Studio under Integration Action, and then click OK.
    9. Under Business rule, click the following parameters one by one, and then click OK.
      • Integration: Select the integration to be triggered.
      • Scenario: Select the specific scenario to be triggered.
      • Payload (optional): Click it to add key-value pairs to the payload that is passed to the scenario.
    10. (Optional) Configure decision points so that the integration scenario is triggered only when a condition is satisfied.
    11. Save the plan.

    For details about task plans and how to add a task plan, see Related topics below.

    Trigger integration by listener

    To trigger an integration scenario through the listener, select the Enable Listener check box when creating the scenario. For details, see Listener.

    Trigger integration by scheduler

    To trigger an integration scenario through the scheduler, create a schedule (Administration > Utilities > Integration > Integration Studio > Scheduler tab), and select the integration and scenario to be triggered on the Scenario page. For details, see Scheduler.

    Trigger integration manually

    To manually trigger an integration scenario, perform the following steps:

    1. From the main menu, select Administration > Utilities > Integration.
    2. Go to Integration Studio.
    3. In the left pane, select the scenario to trigger under the corresponding integration.
    4. Click Run scenario on the toolbar.

    Step 6. Monitor integration execution status

    After an integration scenario is triggered, you can view the integration execution history on these pages in the Integration Module:

    • The Execution history page
    • The Endpoints page

    View execution history on the Execution history page

    Click Execution history ( ) on the Integration or Scenario page to view the scenario-level execution history for the current integration or scenario.

    Work with scenario-level execution history

    The Execution history page lists each execution of the scenarios in the current integration or the current scenario, depending on whether you accessed the page by clicking the button on the Integration page or Scenario page.

    Click the link in the Id column to open a page that displays the rule-level history for that particular execution. Click any of the other columns to display general scenario execution details in the sidebar. Such details include the history Id, trigger payload, and label. To adjust the size of the sidebar, move your mouse pointer to the left edge of the sidebar until its shape changes to a double-headed arrow, and then drag the edge to the desired position.

    Work with rule-level execution history

    On the Execution history page for a particular scenario execution, one record corresponds to one rule in the scenario. Click a record to view the execution details for the rule in the sidebar. See the Important history fields section below for more information. To adjust the size of the sidebar, move your mouse pointer to the left edge of the sidebar until its shape changes to a double-headed arrow, and then drag the edge to the desired position.

    On the execution history page, you can perform the following actions:

    • Filter the execution history records.
    • Delete the selected execution history records. When a Scenario execution history record is deleted, the associated Rule execution history records will also be deleted.
    • Choose which columns to display in the table view. The following columns are available but hidden by default:
      • Sync mode    
      • Correlation Id: This is the value of x-correlation_header_id from the REST call's response. This helps trace the execution log to the corresponding REST call's response.
      • Scenario response    
      • Global transaction Id    
      • Job Id
    • Refresh the execution history records to get the latest data.
    • Rearrange the columns by dragging and dropping them.

    View execution history on the Endpoints page

    Navigate to the Endpoints page, and then click the endpoint for the integration to view the integration execution history. On this page, one record corresponds to one rule in an integration scenario. Click the link in the Id column to open a page that displays the execution history for that rule. See the Important history fields section below for more information.

    If an integration involves multiple target systems, you can view the integration execution history in any endpoint configured in the integration.
    You can't use the Endpoints page to view the execution history for scenarios that contain only local system rules. For such scenarios, you must use the Execution history page to view the history.

    Important history fields

    The following describes some important rule execution history fields.

    • Request details: Contains information about the request sent to the target system (it's empty for Common action rules and Local System rules), such as request header, HTTP method, payload (if available).
    • Response details: Contains information about the response received from the target system (it's empty for Common action rules and Local System rules), such as response header, payload, status code, error message.
    • Expression execution details: Contains the expression and its evaluation result for each parameter (in various sections) of the rule. Exception: The Expression execution details for some input parameters of add/upload attachment actions are not available.
    • Output details: Contains the parsed results for the object defined in the Output section of target system rules and Local System rules, as well as in Prepare Data and Change Data rules.

    Execution history retention period

    By default, the system keeps 30 days of integration execution logs (history). You can change this default value. See Application Setting.
